title: Very solid pour over system
body:
First of all, you can make great coffee with The Coffee Gator. If you're new to pour over, maybe don't use their suggested grounds:water ratio but that's not the hardware's fault.

By adjusting grind size this works for anything from 1 6oz cup to coffee for 4 people. That capacity is nice (and a bit unusual) for pour overs.

Its shape also does a decent job of collecting most of the unfiltered sediment along with a splash of liquid before it pours into your cups. The spout does tend to dribble a bit at the end if you're a neat freak.

The reason this isn't a 5 star review is because a glass carafe/micro-filter system can't be 5 stars. The glass, while seemingly very sturdy in my month of using it, is still glass. And a micro-filter mesh will always have 2 drawbacks:

1. It will never filter out all of the sediment from your coffee

2. It can be easy to damage if you aren't careful with cleaning and storing it

That said, I would definitely give this 4.5 stars. Come on, half star ratings! What are we even doing here?

title: Lovely little coffee maker!
body:
I am a college student, but I usually only drink one cup of coffee a day. So, while looking for a new coffee maker, I wasn't looking for anything too big, especially as I share my small dorm kitchen with my two roommates. I was also interested in experimenting with manual coffee makers; one of my roommates last year had had a Keurig she let me use, but I wasn't too impressed with the results, so I knew I did not want to invest in a pod brewer for myself.

The CoffeeGator pour-over hit the nail on the head. It delivers on all fronts: compact size, sleek design, fairly priced, easy to use, relatively speedy (compared to the average French press), fun to experiment with, and most importantly, a delicious brew. I have never enjoyed drinking coffee black in the past, but now I do at least a few times a week and really enjoy it. I usually use a #2 cone-shaped coffee filter just to make cleanup faster, although going filter-less definitely works, too, and cleanup doesn't take that much effort.

I was going to leave a review when I first bought it back in July, but I kept forgetting to. Yesterday, however, I accidentally dropped the carafe and the top half shattered. I had noticed other Amazon reviews mentioning that CoffeeGator had replaced their brewers for various reasons, so I thought I may as well try to contact them before buying a replacement. I emailed them last night explaining the situation (with a screenshot of my Amazon order) and a little over 12 hours later, they have already graciously responded and shipped out a replacement! I was willing to buy one of their replacement carafes (which isn't as expensive as buying the whole kit again) but was relieved and impressed by their customer service, especially being on a college student's limited budget. Kudos, CoffeeGator!

title: LOVE,LOVE my Coffee Gator Pour over pot and kettle
body:
If you love good, smooth coffee you HAVE to get a Coffee Gator pour over pot and kettle! A friend told me about it a few months ago, but I couldn't imagine better coffee pot better than Keurig coffee. I was watching Amazon daily deals one day a couple of weeks ago, and this pot was on special, so, I ordered it and received it two days later. I think I was weaned on coffee when very young, so, LOVE LOVE coffee!! And LOVE, LOVE MY COFFEE GATOR POUR-OVER POT! I remember as a child, my mother dripping coffee, and I still have her drip pot, but it requires a filter and much more difficult. She would boil water (big mistake)and pour over the coffee, etc. All drip pots aren't created equally.
I tried a few days making my coffee in my new pot, heating my water in the microwave, then using my thermometer to check the temp. That was such pain and took too much time. SO, I ordered the 1.2L gooseneck kettle with built-in thermometer.. WOW! What a difference it has made! I like quick and have used Keurig for 7 years, but to me, this doesn't really take any more time. I fill my kettle the night before with filtered water, then as soon as I go into my kitchen, I turn the burner on while starting my husband's Keurig. It might take 1 min more, but SO worth it. My husband isn't the coffee snob that I am, so he still gets Keurig. üòä It took a while to get the perfect water to coffee ratio, but I have it now. I used to set my Keurig on small setting, approx 6oz. Now, I make a full coffee gator and it fills my big cup perfectly. I am using a New Orleans coffee bean and grind my beans at home. This coffee is sold in grocery stores and it's wonderful but I will go to a local roaster and buy their very freshly roasted beans, which will make even better coffee. I know this is long, but I wanted to cover everything.. oh, almost forgot to mention Coffee Gator's customer service. Awesome, they want their customers to be totally satisfied. They were great even before I bought my pot, answering any questions and helping make the best coffee decision I could make, but truly amazing after the sale, sending hints on making the best coffee. They don't want even one dissatisfied customer. I HIGHLY recommend this loud over pot AND kettle. Now, I'm looking forward to buying the canister to store my beans.

Since I bought this over a year ago, I haven't spent the $5 (or more!) on a Starbucks coffee and I can count on one hand how many times I've used my Keurig. The pour over method enhances and preserves the natural oils and flavoring that you can't get any other way if you want that deep rich coffee flavor. I know, I sound like an advertisement, but seriously it's so good. And for all you short-on-time people - with grinding my own coffee from whole beans, and using an electric kettle for fast water heating, my coffee is ready in less than 5 minutes. Believe me, the extra 4 minutes it takes over a K-Cup is worth every second. And if you just don't have the time for that in the morning, you can brew your coffee the night before and put the carafe in the fridge so your iced coffee is all ready to go in the morning. By the way, Coffee Gator has awesome customer service too. I had a small issue with the second larger carafe I bought from them - they completely stood behind their product and I had a brand new one in very short order. If I ever do need to order another one, I can tell you that I'll be coming straight back to this company to buy it again. Great price and quality and above and beyond excellent customer service. title: Coffee so good, it will ruin you.
body:
My how the tables have come full circle and turned upside down.

I started my love affair with coffee at a young age, addicted the the auto drip coffee. As I grew I became less enamored with it, but I still called her every week. Then things changed on the Honeymoon with my Wife. We stayed a fancy hotel and Coffee, well she was served as a french press. Oh those seductive notes, the rich taste, she lulled me back to her again.

As soon as I got home I got a French Press and never looked back. Now it is 10 years later. Sometimes I give in and get coffee from the coffee machine, but I love the french press still. I started drinking Blonde roast about 2 years ago. I was reading and someone mentioned that blonde roast is better as a pour over. My coworker also parroted that pour over is the best coffee.

Pour over? What the heck is that? French press all the way baby that's all there is to it. Most people see Pour over as a uniquely Hipster thing. A level of coffee snobbery I have left un-attained. And yet... I ordered this on curiosity. I reviewed a bunch of options, and decided that I didn't want to go back to using filters, so metal mesh is fine for me. This seemed to be the best between aesthetics, build quality, and reviews.

My first pot of this was Andaqui 100% Colombian, my second Blond roast from Starbucks... I wonder now if I ever truly tasted coffee before. I told my wife that I fear for my immortal soul by throwing in with the Hipster. She said we can't be friends anymore, she jests, but I thought... "I'm not sure I can go back to normal coffee now". This tasted so good I just about slapped your mama thinking about it.

If there is a fault with this product, I would hazard to say I would like more capacity because I am a coffee sharer. I love sharing the experience and I will drink this whole pot by myself as it pours about 1 normal cup for me. Would I purchase again? Yes Yes and a million times Yes. French press... whats her number again? I forget... Anyone want a french press?

title: A high-quality product, and a company that stands behind it with stellar service!
body:
This is a high-quality product that makes excellent coffee. But even more importantly, Coffee Gator's customer service is absolutely stellar!!

I bought this coffee maker almost exactly one year ago, and have used it daily since I received it. The materials are solid. It is easy to use. It makes delicious coffee! The filter traps virtually all of the unpleasant sediment, leaving mere traces at the bottom, subtle enough to drink without any problem.

All was good until recently when the water began dripping through the filter so slowly that it became painful to use. I tried boiling the filter in a large pot with water and distilled vinegar, and allowed it to then soak overnight. Then, I cleaned it using warm soapy water and a soft dishcloth - as I always do. It improved the flow somewhat, but not enough to make it useable - still too slow. I have consistently tried to take good care of the filter, to keep it operating well, and I don't know what I might have done differently to avoid the clogging problem.

I contacted Coffee Gator by email, and I received a very prompt and courteous reply from Viktoria. She asked me to send a photo of the filter, provide my order number, and describe my cleaning practices. I did as she asked, and she generously offered to send me a new filter free of charge!

Unfortunately, she and her team did not have any suggestions about how I might change my usage practices to avoid future clogging, and it seems to me that a filter of this construction should not become so clogged after just one year, and with the care that I have given it. But how can one complain much when confronted with such kind and generous customer support?

Thank you, Viktoria and Coffee Gator! I continue to be a loyal Coffee Gator customer.

title: Not a bad system but could use a few quality upgrades
body:
I would really love to give this more stars but I guess I take my ratings system a little more serious than everyone thinking everything is 5 stars. To me, 5 stars is given when its A) clearly the best product in that market segment or B) when it far exceeds expectations for the price.

While the Coffee Gator does make a great cup of coffee and while it does the job, it's no better than some of the other options out there. I guess what I'm disappointed in that Coffee Gator didn't decide to make a $40 product to compete with the $40 Chemex, and sell it on the no filters alone. I think and extra $4-5 in product costs would have gone a long way in making Coffee Gator the best pour over system in the market.

Pros: Pretty good system for the money. Good size. Good price. Don't need to replace the filters.

Cons: Made in China (almost a given) Thin glass (I doubt this will make a year with granite counters/etc). Poorly defined pouring spout makes spills more common. Cheaply made filter. They could have invested a few more bucks for thicker metal and better welding process.

Overall it's not a bad system and I'm happy with what it does. But I just feel that for a few bucks more they could have thicker glass to make it more durable (I know, more breaks equal more sales) and a better quality filter would make this a 5 star product and still fit in the $40 price range.

I also like that this is easy to clean and don't have to use coffee filter and the associated mess.

OK, bottom line is that I really like the Coffee Gator and it looks good.

Why only 4 stars? On my Coffee Gator the graduations on the vessel seem to be inaccurate. The company told me they consider a cup of coffee to be 11 ounces of water as do other companies. Some companies consider 6 ounces of water to be a cup of coffee. What ever.

However I felt that the graduations were wrong. Using a Paterson graduated beaker that is about 3.5" in diameter showed the following discrepancies.

CG = Coffee Gator vs. Paterson beaker made in England with graduations for US and English fluid ounces and also Milliliters.

CG 4 cups indicated is 19.5 US fluid ounces; a little over 20 English ounces and 575 ml.

800 ml indicated is really 875 ml.

400 ml indicated is really 485 ml.

None of the above is important unless you are trying to follow a predetermined ratio.

title: Seriously handy, seriously tasty!
body:

Well, when you're used to a French press, you won't notice a significant difference in taste, per-say - though if you're looking for a "lighter brew" (less oils), this will produce a tendency to the lighter side (the water and the coffee simply aren't in contact for the same amount of time!), however... the one HUGE difference you'll become aware of the first time you use it, is CLEAN UP! French press: Why did we insist on "inventing" a new, electric "drip" appliance, when we already had a "perfect" coffee maker?? Clean up? May explain the trend away from the press...
"Pour Over" coffee maker: Wow, that does a good job! I guess we should clean this so that it's ready for round two... What? What do you mean it's done already? Seriously, 1 minute and some running water, and this diddy is good to go - yes... It's that easy!
Do I wish it were half again larger? Sure, but it makes a 20 oz mug of coffee with no problems, so it's not "too small" by any means.
Do I wish I'd tried one before now? Yes sir, I do :) Bloody nice coffee maker, with a well thought out design, and a surprising number of "useful" features (I'll let you discover these for yourself, as that's half the fun!).

title: Easy to use, and easy to clean!
body:
Excellent coffee maker! I love the comfortable handle. The carafe and stainless steel filter is really easy to clean.

Do yourself a favor, make sure your coffee is consistent from batch to batch by using a thermometer to make sure your water is in the correct temperature range. Better yet, use a kettle that has a built-in thermometer, like the one I use: Stainless Steel Gooseneck Stovetop Pour Over Coffee Kettle with Thermometer by Kitchables . Since getting the water temp sorted out, every batch I make has been very, very consistent.

Listen, some people focus too much on measuring out the beans to the gram and measuring out every drippety drop of water to the gram‚Äîto heck with all that. Just buy great coffee that's not been over roasted, grind it evenly, and make sure your water is at the right temperature. Pour the water over the coffee using whatever system you prefer (pour over, aeropress, drip machine, whatever), and voila great coffee. Easy peasy. This isn't rocket science. Higher coffee to water ratio, stronger coffee; lower coffee to water ratio, milder coffee. If you get it too strong, add a touch of water (or dairy product of your choice) to the brewed coffee. Too mild? Add ice and enjoy it cold, not a big deal. Just have fun with it. :)

I then add my my coffee grounds to the filter, and give my filter a quick shake to level out the grounds. By the time that is all done, my water has heated up enough in the kettle to start pouring over the grounds. Within seconds the water has seeped through the filter and the measuring icons on the Gator help me get just the right amount of coffee. And creamer, and bam - bye Starbucks. Great way to save time and money. Well worth the price. Solid glass and metal filter.

title: French press convert!
body:
It was time to change my press, since the mesh along the sides of the plunger were fraying to an annoying level. I've had pour over coffee before, but never at home. For one thing, I have no desire to use paper filters to make my coffee. I was intrigued by Coffee Gator's fine mesh filter cone.

I received it in perfect condition and it holds more coffee than I had estimated. You can easily serve 2 people 16oz cups from one pour session. Takes a a few minutes and I have even more flavorful coffee than the press.

All I do is rinse in the sink and air dry. I wish there was a version I could take on camping trips.

title: Great pour over solution
body:
I've been using this carafe and reuseable filter for over two years. It's a very fine stainless filter so the sediment is minimal. You can of course add a paper filter if you wish- I don't. Control your beans, grind, water temperature and proportions, and you will make outstanding coffee.

The company states it is not recommended to wash the carafe in a dishwasher. I have ignored this mostly but am also on my third carafe in two years, so take that into account when you decide how to clean it. Otherwise the system is elegant and very functional.
